DataElement.preferredName: Specimen Donor Cellular Infusion Cell Count  Assessment Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the final result type of cells in a sample used after hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT).

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Specimen Donor Cellular Infusion Cell Count  Assessment
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to the final result of cells in a sample used after hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT).

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Specimen; a bit of tissue or blood or urine that is taken or used for research purposes.

Concepts.definition: A part of a thing, or of several things, taken to demonstrate or to determine the character of the whole, e.g. a substance, or portion of material obtained for use in testing, examination, or study; particularly, a preparation of tissue or bodily fluid taken for examination or diagnosis.

ObjectClass.changeDescription: Updated Definition and alternate names D Warzel

Property.preferredName: Donor Cellular Infusion Cell Count Assessment
Property.preferredDefinition: A form of adoptive immunotherapy used after hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). Lymphocytes from the original stem cell donor are given to the HSCT recipient, after the transplant, to augment an antitumor immune response (graft-versus-tumor), or ensure that the donor stem cells remain engrafted. Although lymphocytes are the most commonly used cell, other cells including fibroblasts, mesenchymal or dendritic cells may be delivered to affect chimerism, treat Graft vs. Host Disease, treat viral infections or Post Transplant Lymphoproliferative Disease or other novel uses under investigation.:A procedure to determine the number of cells in a sample. Also used to mean the result of such a procedure.:The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of.

Concepts.definition: A form of adoptive immunotherapy used after hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). Lymphocytes from the original stem cell donor are given to the HSCT recipient, after the transplant, to augment an antitumor immune response (graft-versus-tumor), or ensure that the donor stem cells remain engrafted. Although lymphocytes are the most commonly used cell, other cells including fibroblasts, mesenchymal or dendritic cells may be delivered to affect chimerism, treat Graft vs. Host Disease, treat viral infections or Post Transplant Lymphoproliferative Disease or other novel uses under investigation.
A procedure to determine the number of cells in a sample.
The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: attributes of a patient's laboratory sample, including the source, condition, and fixative.

ValueDomain.preferredName: Specimen Donor Cellular Infusion Cell Count Type
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the type of cells in a sample used after hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT).

PermissibleValues.value: Pre-thaw Infused Cell Counts for Cord Blood
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Pre-thaw Infused Cell Counts for Cord Blood

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Pre-thaw Infused Cell Counts for Cord Blood
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Earlier in time or order.: The process whereby heat changes something from a solid to a liquid.: A form of adoptive immunotherapy used after hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). Lymphocytes from the original stem cell donor are given to the HSCT recipient, after the transplant, to augment an antitumor immune response (graft-versus-tumor), or ensure that the donor stem cells remain engrafted. Although lymphocytes are the most commonly used cell, other cells including fibroblasts, mesenchymal or dendritic cells may be delivered to affect chimerism, treat Graft vs. Host Disease, treat viral infections or Post Transplant Lymphoproliferative Disease or other novel uses under investigation.: Blood present in the umbilical vessels at the time of delivery. If cryopreserved at birth, cord blood can serve as a source of autologous lymphocytes for transplantation to a patient later diagnosed and treated for leukemia or lymphoma.

Concepts.definition: The process whereby heat changes something from a solid to a liquid.

A form of adoptive immunotherapy used after hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). Lymphocytes from the original stem cell donor are given to the HSCT recipient, after the transplant, to augment an antitumor immune response (graft-versus-tumor), or ensure that the donor stem cells remain engrafted. Although lymphocytes are the most commonly used cell, other cells including fibroblasts, mesenchymal or dendritic cells may be delivered to affect chimerism, treat Graft vs. Host Disease, treat viral infections or Post Transplant Lymphoproliferative Disease or other novel uses under investigation.

Blood present in the umbilical vessels at the time of delivery. If cryopreserved at birth, cord blood can serve as a source of hematopoietic progenitor cells for transplantation to a patient later diagnosed and treated for a hematopoietic disorder.

PermissibleValues.value: Infused Cell Counts For Bone Marrow or PBSC
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Infused Cell Counts For Bone Marrow or PBSC

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Infused Cell Counts For Bone Marrow or PBSC
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A form of adoptive immunotherapy used after hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). Lymphocytes from the original stem cell donor are given to the HSCT recipient, after the transplant, to augment an antitumor immune response (graft-versus-tumor), or ensure that the donor stem cells remain engrafted. Although lymphocytes are the most commonly used cell, other cells including fibroblasts, mesenchymal or dendritic cells may be delivered to affect chimerism, treat Graft vs. Host Disease, treat viral infections or Post Transplant Lymphoproliferative Disease or other novel uses under investigation.: To determine the number or amount of something; the result of this activity.: The reason of something. : The tissue occupying the spaces of bone. It consists of blood vessel sinuses and a network of hematopoietic cells which give rise to the red cells, white cells, and megakaryocytes. : Immature cells found circulating in the bloodstream. New blood cells develop from peripheral stem cells.

Concepts.definition: A form of adoptive immunotherapy used after hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). Lymphocytes from the original stem cell donor are given to the HSCT recipient, after the transplant, to augment an antitumor immune response (graft-versus-tumor), or ensure that the donor stem cells remain engrafted. Although lymphocytes are the most commonly used cell, other cells including fibroblasts, mesenchymal or dendritic cells may be delivered to affect chimerism, treat Graft vs. Host Disease, treat viral infections or Post Transplant Lymphoproliferative Disease or other novel uses under investigation.
Determining the number or amount of something.
The tissue occupying the spaces of bone. It consists of blood vessel sinuses and a network of hematopoietic cells which give rise to the red cells, white cells, and megakaryocytes.
An immature (progenitor) cell circulating in the peripheral blood.  It has the capacity for replication and differentiation to mature blood cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Post-thaw Infused Cell Counts for Cord Blood
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Happening at a time subsequent to a reference time; later in time or order.: The process whereby heat changes something from a solid to a liquid.: A form of adoptive immunotherapy used after hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). Lymphocytes from the original stem cell donor are given to the HSCT recipient, after the transplant, to augment an antitumor immune response (graft-versus-tumor), or ensure that the donor stem cells remain engrafted. Although lymphocytes are the most commonly used cell, other cells including fibroblasts, mesenchymal or dendritic cells may be delivered to affect chimerism, treat Graft vs. Host Disease, treat viral infections or Post Transplant Lymphoproliferative Disease or other novel uses under investigation.: To determine the number or amount of something; the result of this activity.: Blood present in the umbilical vessels at the time of delivery. If cryopreserved at birth, cord blood can serve as a source of autologous lymphocytes for transplantation to a patient later diagnosed and treated for leukemia or lymphoma.

Concepts.definition: Happening at a time subsequent to a reference time; later in time or order.
The process whereby heat changes something from a solid to a liquid.

A form of adoptive immunotherapy used after hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). Lymphocytes from the original stem cell donor are given to the HSCT recipient, after the transplant, to augment an antitumor immune response (graft-versus-tumor), or ensure that the donor stem cells remain engrafted. Although lymphocytes are the most commonly used cell, other cells including fibroblasts, mesenchymal or dendritic cells may be delivered to affect chimerism, treat Graft vs. Host Disease, treat viral infections or Post Transplant Lymphoproliferative Disease or other novel uses under investigation.
Determining the number or amount of something.

Blood present in the umbilical vessels at the time of delivery. If cryopreserved at birth, cord blood can serve as a source of hematopoietic progenitor cells for transplantation to a patient later diagnosed and treated for a hematopoietic disorder.
